data.title: Authors similar to Greg Egan?
data.meta_description: I really like Greg Egan's novels and stories, specially Quarantine, Permutation City and Axiomatic. I have Teranesia, Luminous and Diaspora in my to-read...
data.text:
Similar to Egan in what way?

I suspect you probably mean the "Hard SF" (rigorous extrapolation of current scientific knowledge) aspect of the writing with perhaps a detached narrative style.

No one I know is like Greg Egan except Greg Egan; he's, IMO, the best "Hard SF" exponent currently writing. There are other writers who people regard to be "Hard SF". Maybe you could try a few of them.

The Recommendation thread is a good place to start.

Writers that are regarded as "Hard SF" (with Wikipedia links):

Hal Clement:

"MISSION OF GRAVITY" is regarded as a Hard SF classic.

Stephen Baxter:

He came to prominence with "THE TIME SHIPS", a sequel to H.G. Wells "THE TIME MACHINE" but has been writing some fine Hard SF. Try the first of his Manifold trilogy, "MANIFOLD: TIME" or the XEELEE SEQUENCE starting with "RAFT".

Greg Bear:

"BLOOD MUSIC"

Charles Sheffield:

"THE WEB BETWEEN WORLDS" and "BETWEEN THE STROKES OF NIGHT". He wrote my favourite novelette, "GEORGIA ON MY MIND".

David Brin:

"EARTH" is an excellent stand-alone. He's best known for his "UPLIFT" series.

Nancy Kress:

Another excellent writer. She explores more the impact of molecular biology (genetic engineering) rather than physical sciences. Try the series that starts with "BEGGARS IN SPAIN".

Kim Stanley Robinson:

The "MARS" trilogy, starting with "RED MARS" is about human exploration & colonisation of Mars.

Vernor Vinge:

"A FIRE UPON THE DEEP" & "A DEEPNESS IN THE SKY". He's also brilliant.

Charles Stross:

My current favourite SF writer. His recent novel "ACCELERANDO" traces the lives of three generations of a family as they live through a technological singularity. "ACCELERANDO" is available as a free download.

The SF part of sffworld needs a "If you like ^^^^^ then you might like #####" thread.

EDIT:

Was just informed that there is a Sci-fi: If you like ^^^ then you might like ### thread after all. Thanks to monty mike!

Does this help?

Thank you very much for your answers. In fact, I've already read some of the authors you have proposed (Charles Sheffield, Vinge, Greg Bear) and I have most of the others (Erath, Red Mars, Beggars in Spain...) in my shelves waiting to be read (so many books, so little time...). But I don't think that any of them (at least the ones I've read) are exactly what I'm looking for, though I like them all.

In fact, I'm not referring only to hard SF, but specially to that kind of hard SF which is deeply linked with philosophical speculation. I think that Egan is a master in that (and I agree that he is one of the best SF writers nowadays). For instance, in his novels and stories he deals with many important and deep questions: What is the conscience? What is it to be human? What is reality? All these problems are addressed by means of concepts and ideas from modern science (quantum physics, for example) and are explored thoroughly. I love that!!! And I have found no other author (with the only exception of Ted Chiang, possibly) which deals at the same time with borderlands of science and the implications to modern philosophy. That's what I'm looking for!!!

In the "what it means to be human" mode, definitely check out "Accelerando". With the ability to upload 'yourself' and spawn multiple copies, who is 'you"?, is just one of the themes explored.

The John C. Wright trilogy is also an excellent exploration of the 'identity' theme.

I also really liked Tony Daniel's "Metaplanetary", which has 'large arrays of personalities' or entities that are an aggregation of different personalities. Unfortunately, the publishers has declined to print the conclusion to that trilogy.

With the Ted Chiang collection & Greg Egan, you're basically reading the best exponents of this sort of writing. You are not going to get more of the same unless they clone themselves

There are other writers who are, IMHO, 'as good', but for different reasons.

Trouble is when you've read writers this good, it's hard to go back to the 'lesser' stuff.

Archren said:

In the deep philsophical speculation mode, you might enjoy the "Golden Age" trilogy by John C. Wright, which starts with the book "The Golden Age." It is really an amazing piece of work, almost entirely hard SF, very far-future, very concerned with philosophy and questions of identity. Try it, I think you might like it.

Sure! How could I forget about John C. Wright? I have read "The golden age" and I was very surprised by the way he introduces philosophical problems (specially, as you said, that of identity) and also genuine sense of wonder. Very, very good I have the two other volumes of the reilogy in the to-read stack

In fact I think that we are living a good time for SF. Since I began reading in English (about one year ago) I discovered lots of very good authors which have not been translated into Spanish yet. And I have a long list of new (at least to me) authors which I want to read: Linda Nagata, Karl Schroeder, Wil McCarthy...
